elements.title: Seven-Gate Progressive Disclosure for Move-In Orientation
elements.problem: Move-in is the Belly of the Whale -- the guest crosses the threshold from digital evaluation into physical habitation. Campbell's Inanna is stripped at seven gates, each removing a layer of adornment before she stands 'naked before the throne' (lines 393-396). For the guest, move-in strips away each layer of listing-page expectation and replaces it with physical reality. The information architecture challenge: what to disclose when, so that each layer of uncertainty is addressed at the right moment in the guest's descent. Currently, the House Manual is delivered as a single document after acceptance -- a monolithic information dump that corresponds to Inanna being stripped of all garments at once rather than gate by gate. The guest either reads everything (cognitive overload) or reads nothing (arrives unprepared). Neither outcome supports the structured initiation that Campbell's model prescribes.
elements.solution: Decompose move-in information into seven sequential disclosures, each timed to the guest's psychological readiness and physical proximity to the space. Gate 1 (post-acceptance, 48h before): neighborhood overview -- transit, walkability, local landmarks. Gate 2 (24h before): access logistics -- building entry, key/lockbox, parking. Gate 3 (12h before): top 3 house rules distilled from the full manual. Gate 4 (arrival): prompt arrival confirmation. Gate 5 (first hour): full House Manual surfaced with a 'settling in' navigation frame. Gate 6 (first evening): host check-in facilitation. Gate 7 (next morning): first-night debrief. Each gate provides information that strips one layer of the guest's uncertainty, converting the raw unknown of a stranger's home into a structured, comprehensible environment.

evidence.quote: Upon her entering the first gate, the shugurra, the 'crown of the plain' of her head, was removed... 'Extraordinarily, O Inanna, have the decrees of the nether world been perfected, O Inanna, do not question the rites of the nether world.'
evidence.insight: The gatekeeper's refrain -- 'do not question the rites' -- is the platform's assurance that the disclosure sequence is deliberate. Each gate strips exactly one ornament (one expectation), and the guest is not meant to understand the full picture at any single gate. The rite IS the sequence. Delivering all information at once would be like stripping all garments simultaneously -- traumatic rather than transformative.

evidence.quote: Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them. Show something useful first. Offer to refine after.
evidence.insight: Each gate delivers value (neighborhood context, access details, key rules) before requesting engagement (arrival confirmation, check-in, feedback). The disclosure pattern mirrors the discovery principle: show something useful first, then invite participation.

evidence.quote: I stood before a dark cave, wanting to go in, and I shuddered at the thought that I might not be able to find my way back.
evidence.insight: The guest at the front door is in this exact phenomenological state. The seven-gate sequence converts the 'dark cave' into an illuminated corridor, where each step forward is accompanied by a revelation that reduces the shudder.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Time-gated, proximity-ordered. Information closest to the physical experience (access logistics, house rules) takes precedence over contextual information (neighborhood overview) as the guest approaches move-in day. The hierarchy inverts as time progresses: 48h out, context > logistics; 12h out, logistics > context; post-arrival, operational details > everything else.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Seven sequential messages/surfaces, each timed to a specific moment in the guest's approach to the space. No gate contains more than one category of information. Each gate's content is self-contained and actionable without reference to other gates. The full House Manual is never the first thing disclosed -- it is Gate 5, after the guest is physically present and ready to absorb operational details.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Each gate message should be readable in under 60 seconds. Gate 3 (house rules) should contain exactly 3 rules, with a link to the full manual. The arrival confirmation (Gate 4) should be completable in one tap. Total pre-arrival information absorption: under 3 minutes across Gates 1-3.
exclude: Full House Manual before arrival (overwhelming at wrong moment)
Payment or financial details during move-in sequence (irrelevant to the orientation need)
Platform promotional content during move-in (the guest is in the Belly of the Whale, not in discovery)
Host's full profile information (the guest already evaluated this during listing_evaluation and negotiation)

elements.title: Trial Progression Dashboard: Cumulative Stay Record as Wayfinding
elements.problem: The Road of Trials produces 'a multitude of preliminary victories, unretainable ecstasies, and momentary glimpses of the wonderful land' (Campbell, lines 430-431). But the guest's stay dashboard currently presents stays as a flat list -- each stay identical to the last, with no visual or informational marker that distinguishes stay 1 from stay 10. The information architecture fails to communicate progression. Campbell's hero on the Road of Trials accumulates victories that define their growth; the guest accumulates stays that should define theirs. Without a progression-aware information hierarchy, each stay is a disconnected trial with no sense of where the guest stands on the road. The user stories document confirms that the guest's platform history -- 'reviews, familiarity with how things work' -- is a valuable asset, but the current dashboard does not surface this asset to the guest themselves, only to future hosts.
elements.solution: Redesign the stay dashboard as a progression timeline rather than a flat list. (1) Primary information: a visual timeline showing completed stays as filled nodes and upcoming stays as open nodes. The current stay is highlighted. This gives the guest an instant sense of position on the Road of Trials. (2) Secondary information: cumulative metrics displayed above the timeline -- total stays completed, average review score given and received, total nights spent. These are the hero's accumulating trophies. (3) Tertiary information: per-stay detail cards accessible by tapping a node. Each card shows that stay's dates, review exchanged, any notable events (date change, host message). (4) Progression markers: at stay 3, stay 6, and the final stay, surface brief transformation reflections -- 'You have completed your first month' or 'Halfway through your lease.' These markers are Campbell's 'momentary glimpses of the wonderful land' made visible.

evidence.quote: Dragons have now to be slain and surprising barriers passed -- again, again, and again. Meanwhile there will be a multitude of preliminary victories, unretainable ecstasies, and momentary glimpses of the wonderful land.
evidence.insight: The 'preliminary victories' are individual completed stays. The 'momentary glimpses of the wonderful land' are the moments when the guest realizes the arrangement is working. The information architecture must make both visible: the victories as filled nodes on the timeline, the glimpses as progression markers that acknowledge the guest's growth.

evidence.quote: An experienced guest applying to a new host is cross-activation in action. Their history, their reviews, their familiarity with how things work -- it all reduces the host's anxiety.
evidence.insight: The cumulative metrics (stays completed, reviews exchanged) are not just internal data -- they become the guest's marketplace credential. By surfacing them on the guest's own dashboard, the platform helps the guest understand that their stay history is building toward something valuable beyond the current lease.

evidence.quote: The hero is covertly aided by the advice, amulets, and secret agents of the supernatural helper whom he met before his entrance into this region.
evidence.insight: The progression dashboard itself is a supernatural helper -- it provides the guest with a map of their own journey, making visible what would otherwise be invisible. Without the map, the hero wanders the Road of Trials with no sense of how far they have come or how far they have yet to go.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Progression-first. The primary hierarchy level is the guest's position on the timeline (where am I on the Road of Trials?). Secondary is cumulative metrics (what have I accumulated?). Tertiary is per-stay detail (what happened at each trial?). This inverts the typical chronological-list hierarchy, which puts recency first and progression nowhere.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Timeline view is always visible as the dashboard's primary surface. Cumulative metrics are persistent (visible without scrolling). Per-stay details are expandable (tap to reveal). Progression markers appear at defined intervals and remain visible after they are triggered. The guest should never need to scroll past the timeline to find basic lease navigation.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The timeline should communicate the guest's position in under 2 seconds of visual scanning. Cumulative metrics should be limited to 4 numbers maximum (stays completed, reviews, average rating, nights). Progression markers should be no more than one sentence each.
exclude: Payment details on the stay dashboard (these belong in a financial section, not the trial progression view)
Host management actions (date changes, messaging) buried below the timeline -- these should be accessible from the current stay node, not from a separate section
Historical stays that require horizontal scrolling -- the timeline should accommodate the full lease in the viewport

elements.title: Counter-Offer Transparency: Surfacing the Goddess Behind the Terms
elements.problem: When a host counter-offers, the guest sees changed numbers: duration reduced, price adjusted, dates shifted. Campbell's tale of the five brothers at the well reveals what happens when the hero sees only the surface: Fergus encounters the hag and says 'sooner than give thee a kiss I would perish of thirst!' (line 700). He sees the ugly surface (unfavorable terms) and rejects the offer. Only Niall, who sees past the surface to the person, discovers 'Royal Rule.' The information architecture of the counter-offer screen determines whether the guest is Fergus or Niall. Currently, counter-offers foreground the transactional delta (what changed) and background the relational context (who changed it and why). This creates a Fergus architecture: the guest's first impression is 'my terms were rejected' rather than 'the host is proposing a different partnership.' Campbell warns that the goddess is 'reduced to inferior states' by 'deficient eyes' (line 671) -- the counter-offer architecture is the lens through which the guest sees the host, and if the lens is transactional, the host is reduced to a number.
elements.solution: Restructure the counter-offer surface to lead with relational context and follow with transactional details. (1) First scan zone: the host's identity and message. Show the host's name, photo, and any note they attached to the counter. If no note, show the host's response time and engagement pattern ('This host responded within 4 hours -- they are actively engaged'). (2) Second scan zone: a side-by-side comparison of original terms and proposed terms, with the delta highlighted in neutral (not red/negative) visual treatment. Each changed term should include a brief contextual note: 'Duration: 16 weeks --> 10 weeks. This affects your nightly rate: $X --> $Y.' (3) Third scan zone: response options that include messaging as a primary path, not a secondary one. 'Accept,' 'Suggest different terms,' 'Message [Host Name] about this.' (4) Persistent context: the guest's original proposal summary remains visible so they can compare without memory load.

evidence.quote: 'Is it guarding the well thou art?' he asked, and she said: 'it is.' 'Dost thou licence me to take away some water?' 'I do,' she consented, 'yet only so that I have of thee one kiss on my cheek.' 'Not so,' said he... 'sooner than give thee a kiss I would perish of thirst!'
evidence.insight: Fergus sees the well-guardian's request (a kiss = accepting different terms) as ugly and refuses. The information architecture that shows changed numbers without relational context produces Fergus guests -- they see the delta and refuse. The architecture must help the guest see the host (the well-guardian) as a person proposing partnership, not a system imposing unwanted changes.

evidence.source: user-stories-initial-analysis.md, 'Messaging is the highest cross-activation story' section
evidence.quote: When a guest messages a host, that's not just UX convenience -- it's the moment two strangers begin to trust each other through the platform.
evidence.insight: Making messaging a primary response option on the counter-offer screen is not a UX nicety -- it is the mechanism by which the Fergus reflex is interrupted. The guest who can ask 'why 10 weeks instead of 16?' before deciding is far more likely to discover the partnership behind the terms.

evidence.quote: By deficient eyes she is reduced to inferior states; by the evil eye of ignorance she is spellbound to banality and ugliness. But she is redeemed by the eyes of understanding. The hero who can take her as she is... is potentially the king of her created world.
evidence.insight: The counter-offer architecture IS the lens through which the guest sees the host. Deficient architecture (numbers first, person second) produces 'deficient eyes.' The redesigned architecture gives the guest 'eyes of understanding' by surfacing the host-as-person before the host-as-terms.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Person-first, terms-second. The host's identity and message occupy the primary hierarchy level. The term comparison occupies the secondary level. Response options occupy the tertiary level. This inverts the typical form-response architecture where terms dominate and the person is a sidebar element.
elements.disclosure_pattern: All information visible on a single screen without scrolling for standard counter-offers (1-2 changed terms). For complex counter-offers (3+ changes), the host's identity and message are always above the fold, with term details scrollable below. The messaging response option is always visible in the viewport, never scrolled off-screen.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The host's relational context (name, photo, note) should be parseable in under 3 seconds. The term comparison should present no more than 3 deltas per screen, each with a one-line contextual explanation. Total comprehension time for a standard counter-offer: under 15 seconds.
exclude: Negative framing of changed terms ('Your duration was reduced' -- instead use 'The host suggests 10 weeks')
Legal or contractual language in the term comparison
Platform policy explanations within the counter-offer view (link to policy if needed, but do not embed it)
The guest's financial loss framing ('You will pay $X more per night') -- instead show both the old and new nightly rate neutrally

elements.title: Amulet Framing: Platform Tools as Supernatural Helpers, Not Bureaucratic Requirements
elements.problem: Campbell describes the hero being 'covertly aided by the advice, amulets, and secret agents of the supernatural helper' (lines 22-24). The platform's tools during active_lease -- the Date Change Tool, the messaging system, the cleaning photo submission, the Stays Manager -- are these amulets. But the platform currently presents them as operational requirements rather than aids. 'Submit your cleaning photos' reads as compliance. 'Request a date change' reads as permission-seeking. The information architecture frames the guest as a subject of the platform's rules rather than a hero equipped with the platform's tools. This framing produces what Campbell identifies in the Woman as Temptress section: 'every failure to cope with a life situation must be laid, in the end, to a restriction of consciousness' (lines 813-814). The guest who sees the tools as constraints restricts their consciousness to mere compliance; the guest who sees them as amulets expands their consciousness to active navigation.
elements.solution: Reframe every active-lease tool's information architecture to position the guest as the agent, not the subject. (1) Date Change Tool: rename from 'Request Date Change' to 'Adjust Your Schedule.' The information frame shifts from permission to agency. Show the tool as a calendar interface where the guest can see and manipulate their own stay dates, with host approval framed as 'confirmation' rather than 'permission.' (2) Cleaning photos: rename from 'Submit Cleaning Photos' to 'Show Your Space Is Ready.' The frame shifts from compliance to ritual completion -- the hero presenting evidence of their trial's honorable conclusion. (3) Arrival notification: rename from 'Notify Host of Arrival' to 'Mark Your Arrival.' The guest is the one marking the threshold crossing, not reporting to the host. (4) Stay review: frame as 'Reflect on This Stay' rather than 'Rate This Stay.' The review becomes the hero's own reflection on the trial, not a score assigned to the host. Each reframing uses active voice with the guest as subject, and the platform's role is framed as facilitation ('we will let the host know') rather than governance ('the host must approve').

evidence.quote: The hero is covertly aided by the advice, amulets, and secret agents of the supernatural helper whom he met before his entrance into this region.
evidence.insight: The amulets are covert -- the hero does not experience them as external rules but as extensions of their own capacity. The platform's tools must feel the same way: natural extensions of the guest's agency within the shared space, not impositions from an external authority.

evidence.source: user-stories-initial-analysis.md, 'Authentication should be invisible until it matters' section
evidence.quote: Authentication should be invisible until it matters. Inline auth pop-up, not a full-page redirect. Users don't lose search context.
evidence.insight: The invisibility principle applies to all platform tools during active_lease. The tools should be available when needed and invisible when not. They should feel like the guest's own instruments, not the platform's monitoring mechanisms. The guest should encounter the Date Change Tool because they want to adjust their schedule, not because the platform requires them to submit a request.

evidence.quote: Every failure to cope with a life situation must be laid, in the end, to a restriction of consciousness.
evidence.insight: A guest who perceives the platform's tools as constraints has restricted their consciousness to the role of 'tenant following rules.' A guest who perceives them as amulets has expanded their consciousness to 'hero navigating a shared-living adventure.' The information architecture determines which consciousness the guest develops.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Agency-first. Every tool surface leads with what the guest can do, not what the platform requires. The guest's available actions are the primary hierarchy level. The platform's facilitation role (notifying host, recording the action) is secondary and disclosed inline as supporting context, never as the primary frame.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Tools appear contextually -- the Date Change Tool surfaces when the guest views their calendar, cleaning photos surface at departure, arrival marking surfaces on the stay's start date. Tools do not appear in a separate 'requirements' section. They are embedded in the guest's natural flow through the stay cycle.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Each tool interaction should require no more than 2 taps to initiate and 1 confirmation to complete. The reframed labels should be under 5 words each. Supporting context (what happens after the guest acts) should be a single sentence displayed inline.
exclude: Permission-seeking frames ('Request approval to...', 'Ask the host to...')
Platform-centric language ('Split Lease requires...', 'Per platform policy...')
Negative consequences framing ('Failure to submit cleaning photos will...')

elements.title: Transformation Credential: Making the Guest's Initiation Visible to Themselves and to Hosts
elements.problem: Campbell's Apotheosis marks the moment the hero 'transcends life with its peculiar blind spot' (line 1719). For the guest, this transcendence is the accumulated capacity for shared living -- a skill set and disposition that grows with each completed stay. But the platform's information architecture does not make this capacity visible to the guest. Reviews are shown to hosts; stay counts are stored in databases; trust scores are calculated behind the scenes. The guest who has completed 20 stays across two leases has undergone genuine transformation, but the platform reflects none of this back to them. Campbell's Bodhisattva who 'permeated the whole texture of existence with the divine grace of his assisting presence' (lines 1811-1812) is the experienced guest whose history makes the marketplace better for everyone -- but only if that history is visible. The information architecture must solve two problems: (1) reflect the guest's transformation back to the guest themselves, and (2) make the transformation visible to future hosts as a trust credential.
elements.solution: Create a dual-facing transformation profile. (1) Guest-facing: the guest's profile includes a 'Your Journey' section that shows total stays completed, total leases, cumulative nights, average review score, and a brief narrative of their platform history. This is not a gamified achievement board -- it is a genuine reflection of experience. The guest sees: 'You have completed 14 stays across 2 leases on Split Lease. Hosts describe you as [composite adjective from reviews].' (2) Host-facing: when the guest applies to a new listing, the host sees a trust credential block embedded in the proposal: verified guest, X completed stays, X positive reviews, member since date. This block is the hero's trophy presented at the next threshold. (3) The transition between guest-facing and host-facing is seamless: the same data powers both views, and the guest understands that their journey section IS their marketplace credential. This collapses the distinction between self-knowledge and social proof.

evidence.quote: He shattered for himself the bounds of the last threshold... he paused: he made a vow that before entering the void he would bring all creatures without exception to enlightenment; and since then he has permeated the whole texture of existence with the divine grace of his assisting presence.
evidence.insight: The experienced guest's history IS the 'divine grace of assisting presence.' Their reviews enlighten future guests. Their trust credential eases future hosts' anxiety. The information architecture must make this contribution visible and valued, transforming the guest's private transformation into a public good.

evidence.quote: When someone who's already used Split Lease applies to a host who's never had a guest, that guest's reputation does the selling. Their history, their reviews, their familiarity with how things work -- it all reduces the host's anxiety.
evidence.insight: Cross-activation depends on the guest's history being visible and legible. The transformation credential makes the guest's initiation journey into a trust signal that activates hosts. This is not a one-way extraction of data -- it is the guest's own achievement, surfaced in a form that benefits them (easier acceptance) and the marketplace (faster trust-building).

evidence.quote: In our dreams the ageless perils, gargoyles, trials, secret helpers, and instructive figures are nightly still encountered; and in their forms we may see reflected not only the whole picture of our present case, but also the clue to what we must do to be saved.
evidence.insight: The guest's journey section is a mirror -- 'the whole picture of our present case.' It shows the guest not just what they have done but what they have become. The reviews, the stays, the nights -- these are the 'instructive figures' of their own initiation, reflected back in a form they can recognize and learn from.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Achievement-first, data-second. The guest-facing profile leads with a narrative summary ('You have completed 14 stays') before showing raw metrics. The host-facing credential leads with the trust signal (verified, X stays, X reviews) before showing detailed history. Both faces use the same data but different hierarchy to match the viewer's need.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Guest-facing: always visible on the guest's profile dashboard. Updated automatically after each completed stay. No guest action required to maintain. Host-facing: embedded in the proposal view as the first information block (per L1 works-003 principle of relational context first). Expandable to show detailed history if the host wants depth.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Guest-facing narrative summary: one sentence. Cumulative metrics: 4 numbers maximum. Host-facing trust credential: 5 data points (verification, stays, reviews, rating, member since). Both views should be comprehensible in under 5 seconds.
exclude: Raw data tables of stay history (these belong in an expandable detail view, not the primary surface)
Comparative metrics ('You are in the top 10% of guests') that create competitive framing
Platform-internal scores or algorithms that the guest cannot understand or influence
Negative history elements surfaced prominently (a single negative review should not dominate the credential)
